ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 2010 TO 31ST MARCH, 2011

(Paper Cmd. 1 of 2010)

 

     Order read for consideration in Committee for Supply [3rd Allotted Day].

 

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

 

 

     Head T – Ministry of National Development (cont.)

 

     Resumption of Debate on Question [5th March 2010],

 

     "That the total sum to be allocated for Head T of the Estimates be reduced by $100." – [Mr Cedric Foo].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

 

Residential property prices

 

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan): Sir, Minister Mah gave a robust and immaculate defence of HDB’s housing policies last week despite the controversial and divisive nature of the topic. He has also shown flexibility in adjusting those policies to plug gaps that have emerged, such as the HDB concessionary loans for second purchase. 

 

     I have one point to add to the cash-over-valuation (COV) issue. COV is "uniquely Singapore". No other jurisdiction has anything like it. As an ex-practising valuer, I am puzzled by it. If there is widespread occurrence of COVs for particular flat types or locations, the COVs should form part of the evidence that constitute the basis of the valuation. In other words, unless the market goes totally ballistic, valuations should move up and reduce the COVs. It would therefore be an anomaly if COV persists. I urge the HDB to review the entire COV issue. 

 

     I also have a point to add to the issue of speculation in the HDB market. Based on anecdotal evidence, there are HDB flat owners who sublet their entire flat in contravention of HDB rules. I have come to know of an estate agent who owns five private properties, who bought a resale flat and promptly sublet the entire flat.  His daughter and grandmother were also found to have done the same thing.  Such "unnatural" demand also helps to fuel price rises. For the rules to be effective, HDB must enforce them vigilantly. 

 

     Let me now turn to the subject of private property, though I must add that the public and private housing markets are not distinct but interrelated and interacts with each other.

 

     The complaints aired in recent months – rising property prices, project sell-outs – are symptomatic of short-term dislocations between the housing market and the overall economy. However, if overall economic growth and property prices continue to diverge for a prolonged period, we run the risk of blowing a real estate bubble, just like that in the US.  

 

     The Government’s recent interventions to cool the housing market albeit in a calibrated manner to avert a property bubble is thus welcome. Coming down with a sledge hammer could lead to a property market crash which is equally, if not, even more unwelcome as this would also have a domino effect on the rest of the economy. The Government would have to continue to vigilantly  monitor the market and act to remove any speculative tendencies.

 

     I would like to highlight one trend which I consider unhealthy – the proliferation of Mickey Mouse housing units. Profit-maximising developers want to push dollars per-square-feet of every unit up. The way to do so without hurting sales is to reduce unit sizes to make them "affordable" on a lump sum basis. Touting such high dollar per-square-feet prices can also influence buyers in the highly sentiment driven market and give the perception that property prices are experiencing steep price rises. The headline screams, "$1,634 per-square-foot for a unit in leafy Siglap."

 

     I would like to ask the Ministry to guard against and/or calibrate the proliferation of such units.

 

Property prices

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I shall talk about more measures to curb property prices.

 

     Sir, in order to curb property prices from escalating further, I would suggest that the three-year minimum observation period for sale of each HDB flat only be imposed on permanent residents (PRs) and foreigners, and not on Singapore citizens. PRs and foreigners should also wait for three years before they are allowed to purchase HDB flats. After all, foreigners and PRs are only allowed to sell their private properties after three years of purchase.

 

 

          The Chairman: Mr Liang Eng Hwa, you have two consecutive cuts. Take them together.

 

Property market

 

     Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah): Sir, Singapore’s private property market is small by both global and regional standards. Coupled with a significant number of foreign buyers and high ownership mobility, our local property market can be quite easily heated up. To complicate matters, we do have en bloc fevers from time to time that cause short-term distortions to the market.

 

     In the last few months, I have heard remarks from friends and in the community such as "just close your eyes and buy, and it would not go wrong!", or at the launches, you hear "no cheque book, no deal", or even some issuing signed blank cheques for property launches. As a result of buoyant activities, prices have moved up sharply.

 

     This was in sharp contrast to last year's COS debate where we were talking about how to help the real estate industry tide through the downturn. Despite a still sluggish economy which is recovering from one of our sharpest recessions, the property market rebounded very strongly in the second half of last year. Once again, our property market has demonstrated its highly volatile nature. Is this a case of a demand-supply mismatch?

 

     Hence, I am glad that the Government has come up with the recent cooling off measures and urge the Government to continue to watch the market closely.

 

     A highly volatile property market is unhealthy for the economy. It may result in more capital and resources being allocated to this sector and thereby depriving long-term investments in other productive sectors.

 

     I would like to ask the Minister to give his thoughts on the state of the current property market. In particular, I hope that the Minister can address the fundamental question as to whether there is sufficient supply to meet the demand in the next one to two years. Are there unusually large numbers of foreign buyers coming to the market and are they one of the causes for the rising prices? Is there evidence of unhealthy speculation in the market?

 

     I would also like to ask the Minister how the Government determines whether the property market is speculative, bubbly or overheating? What are the key indicators and references that the Government uses? Would it be better if the Government adopt a more transparent approach and communicate these to the market? I believe more information and communication will lead to less volatility as well as reduce second-guessing by the market players and participants?

 

     I also hope that Government can look at ways to pre-empt another emergence of the so called "en bloc fever". Excessive en bloc activity could cause distortions to the property market and add volatility in the short term. If too widespread, it is a negative externality to the economy as it adds upward pressure on costs in a tight labour market condition and can contribute to further bottlenecks in the construction industry.


     Besides, en bloc related construction activity can be harmful in many other ways. To the environment, it is extremely wasteful to tear down and rebuild buildings in otherwise great condition. We have also read about how en bloc sales at private estates have heightened tensions and stirred up conflict among neighbours, residents and developers. Some of these disputes end up being played up in the courts, costing involved parties more money and stress. This would certainly destroy the social cohesion that we are trying to foster.

 

     I feel strongly that the Government should look into the en bloc rules and look into ways to slow excessive and wasteful en bloc activity.

 

Limited land resources

 

     Sir, with only about 710 square kilometers and a residing population of almost five million coupled with the aspiration to be one of the leading economic powerhouses in Asia and in the world, land use planning in Singapore is probably the most challenging task of any land planners in the world.

 

     Here, we have to salute the land planners at the Ministry of National development (MND) and Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) for having done a great job for Singapore since independence. Singapore is now a great place to live, work and play in Asia despite our tight land constraints.

 

     Going forward, our limited land resources will be increasingly squeezed again as we embarked on the next phase of economic growth, to be a distinctive global city. How do we plan even smarter so that the land constraint would not impede our future growth and progress? What are our options – short term and long term?

 

     The Economic Strategies Committee (ESC) has also come up with recommendations. I would like to hear also Government's response to the recommendations, and in particular how would the emphasis of land productivity impact the cost of industrial land.

 

Concept plan 2011 – Singapore's future

 

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports and Minister for Transport (Mr Teo Ser Luck): Sir, three years I signed up for a marathon. In all the marathons I have run, there are white strips after white strips on the road. It is a very long road when you think about 42 kilometers of running. But I was actually looking forward to this marathon. It can lead me from one place to another on a pavement, instead of the road. So it led me from the coast, to the lagoon, then to the HDB flats, ran beside the coffee-shops, back to the beach, go into the residential area and finally to the end point. This is what we call pavement running or now popularly-known, park connectors.

 

     I am also very excited that the Ministry of National Development (MND) is talking about building an entire park connector round-island pavement of 150 kilometers. When that is up, you can imagine that families can go trekking for three days two nights – around Singapore, going through industrial areas, residential areas, HDB heartlands, into the city and back to their home.

 

     I have lived in two other cities for a period of time. These cities are filled with a lot of energy and business life, but also a lot of people. However, they have vast land and nature. That is something that Singapore does not have in natural reserves, vast land or nature. But, then, I would say that the credit goes to the Singapore Government and the Ministry of National Development for doing very careful planning to keep our rustic nature. The other day, I signed up for another long distance race of 25 kilometres, that is to run the trails from MacRitchie Reservoir, to Peirce Reservoir, into Bukit Timah, and back. That was only 25 kilometres, but the longest distance is about 100 kilometres. That 100 kilometres takes you round two loops of 50 kilometres. Singapore does have 50 kilometres of trails, and I am not sure if many Singaporeans know that.

 

     We are not just an urban city, we actually have very good reserves and nature to enjoy. I am glad that MND has now launched the Concept Plan 2011 public consultation to plan for the next 50 years. To me, it is a very important project, as a nature-lover and an outdoor-activist. This is not just to plan the infrastructure to contain the population, but it is also to meet the aspirations of citizens like me for quality living, so that they can have the rootedness and sense of belonging.

 

     But we face many challenges, because we have land constraint, a really dense population, changing demographics, an increasingly greying population, a different population mix and environmental changes. I hope that the Concept Plan 2011 has considered all these factors and discussed these issues as well, and how we can overcome these challenges. There will be many trade-offs as you decide how best to position Singapore in land planning, both as a home and as a place for business. There is no easy solution.  That is why the Concept Plan 2011 is important as it looks at the next 40, 50 years to answer these questions. I really hope that you would be able to do the forward planning as well as we did 40 years ago and achieve the same success. Singaporeans will continue to find Singapore a place they can identify with, be proud of and make it their home.

 

Effective land use

 

     Ms Jessica Tan Soon Neo (East Coast): Mr Chairman, Singapore's growing population exerts increasing demand on land use for housing. With the increasing demand for housing, more land parcels are being released for both private and public housing development. The people to land ratio is facing an increasing stress on space. Can the Minister share with the House what criteria and planning considerations are taken, with the increase in people density when planning for the optimal use of land for housing, especially in our mature estates?

 

     As we have more people living on the same plot of land, using the same amenities and increasing the load on the same road transport and public transport networks, what efforts are being made to enhance greenery, to preserve a sense of space and well-being in high-density areas?

 

     The increased density of people in our estates will strain public amenities, transportation infrastructure and carpark facilities. When land parcels are released for development, what considerations are given to capacity planning on the increased demand on existing amenities and load on the physical infrastructure?

 

     What measures does the Ministry have to ensure that there continues to be sufficient open spaces like parks and sporting facilities within the estate, for residents to relax, interact and for recreation activities?

 

     As we all know, living in cities and living in high-dense areas can be really very stressful. As we use space more optimally, let us give consideration to at least having some space for people to relax and, hopefully, continue in our journey of gracious living and quality living.

 

12.15 pm

 

Planning for long-term growth

 

     Mr Lim Biow Chuan (Marine Parade): Sir, earlier this year, the Urban Development Authority (URA) launched its Concept Plan 2011 public consultation exercise. I am glad to note that our city planners take much effort to plan for the long-term development of Singapore. May I ask the Minister whether the planning authorities have considered the total infrastructure of the area when approving developments?

 

 

 

 

 

 

Do the authorities consider whether the roads, the parks and other social amenities are adequate to cope with the expected increase in the number of residents in an area? 

 

     To take an example, URA had previously approved several residential developments in the Katong/Amber Estate area. Thus, we have new condominiums like One Amber, the Aster and the Seaview, all being developed in the area. As the residents started to occupy their apartments, the concern they expressed is whether the roads are able to cope with the expected increase in traffic.  Are there sufficient parking places for the residents in the estate? Are there sufficient social amenities like parks, shopping centres, markets and eating outlets to cater to the additional residents? Would there be heavy traffic congestion during peak hours along the roads in the area? There will also be additional developments coming up soon like the Silver Sea and Shore Residences. These condominiums will bring about another few thousand residents.  Has URA taken into account these additional residents in the area when they approved the developments?  How does URA intend to prevent overcrowding which will add to the social pressure for the residents in the area?

 

Housing for elderly

 

     Dr Fatimah Lateef (Marine Parade): Sir, in the 2008 COS with the vision of the oncoming silver tsunami, I had brought up this.  This year, yet again, a call for reconsideration for a retirement village concept tailored to the needs of Singapore combining elderly capable of independent living, those with assisted living and residential as well as nursing homes, all housed in an area equipped with facilities. Appropriate and relevant staffing will, of course, be required. The well elderly can provide manpower for employment in the retirement village, helping their weaker and immobile counterparts. This integrated concept of dwelling units, nursing homes, stalls, restaurants, etc, which are elderly-friendly and even partly manned by the elderly can certainly cater to their various needs – an extremely wholesome concept for living for our rapidly ageing population. What is MND's take on this retirement village concept this year, this time?

 

 

          The Chairman:  Ms Irene Ng, take your two cuts together.

 

Giving soul to the city

 

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Sir, Singapore seems to be sprouting giant shopping malls everywhere. And now, oversized Integrated Resorts. They scream that we are a consumer city – even a copy-cat city.

 

     You see the same offerings at any other large city in the world. They say nothing about our cultural heritage or our distinctive character.

 

    Sir, we need to inject more soul into the city. We should identify more heritage areas and create a buzz around them while preserving their authentic, old-world charm. This should be done in an integrated masterplan, involving not only the hardware of buildings, but also the software to give the area its own personality.

 

     A great example is Haji Lane and Arab Street – pulsing with the energy of our vibrant culture. A not-so-good example is Boat Quay. Visitors walking along the promenade today will not get a sense of its history. They would not know that it was once a major port in Singapore, or one of the most popular sites for Chinese street story-telling, stunts and opera performances. Why not build a maritime museum along the river and also bring back the aura of that history?

 

     We should also be innovative and creative. Why not use our Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) gantries, bus stops, MRT stations, even rubbish bins, to display our heritage and creativity?  Work with our local artists to hand paint on them. For example, the bus stops and ERP gantries in Orchard Road can have an orchard theme. Those in Chinatown can have a Chinese theme.

 

     It is by involving people that the city evolves its personality. We should also allow people to adopt benches to commemorate a person or an event. For example, a husband can sponsor a bench in Boat Quay in memory of his wife because they used to date there regularly.  Others reading the inscriptions would connect with the gesture.

 

     Sir, it is our unique history, cultural diversity and the human touches which would give the city personality and soul. Then perhaps one day, our slogan can be "Singapore: The City with Soul".

 

 

Green spaces and coastal areas

 

     Sir, go to the East Coast Park on any weekend and you can see crowds of people jostling for space – walking, jogging, cycling, roller-blading, camping, fishing, flying kites, and so on.
 
     All over the island, our parks, beaches and other recreational spaces are getting over-crowded.  It is good that more people are into outdoor activities. However, the whole idea of being outdoors is to have a sense of freedom and space, and to connect with nature.
 
     We need to provide more areas for our often-stressed Singaporeans to get away from it all. Reports about a man with this big problem of not knowing where to row his own kayak, and the rise in illegal fishing, point to the need to give more thought to this.

 

     The Ministry has done a good job of turning this island into a garden city. I especially commend it for building the park connectors. Like Member Teo Ser Luck, I have also enjoyed it tremendously, cycling from East Coast to Changi Village and marvelling at the natural beauty around us.

 

     I would like to ask for an update of the work to link up the major parks, nature reserves and housing estates throughout the island.


     Besides the main island, more should be done to develop our offshore islands into recreational areas, where people can swim, kayak and island-hop.  But please do not turn them into another Sentosa, which has an artificial plastic feel about it.


     When I was in Koh Samui and Phuket, it was easy to hop from island to island on a boat, and to swim and snorkel.  However, the experience was somewhat marred by the hordes of tourists, the pollution of the boat engines and the destruction of corals.

 

     Sir, we should use our own parks and coastal areas to teach Singaporeans, especially the children, to respect the environment and to love nature. Let us have more educational signs to teach them to identify the wildlife species that live under their own noses.

 

     Many Singaporeans did not know that we have rare sambar deers living in the wild until one was recently killed by a car on the Seletar Expressway.  This accident raises a red flag – is encroaching development threatening their survival?

 

     I would like an assurance from the Minister that we are doing all we can to protect the habitat of our wildlife.

 

 

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Chairman, Sir, I thank Members for their questions on land use planning. First of all, Mr Liang Eng Hwa asked about our land use planning policies.  I would like to assure him that the Ministry of National Development's land use policies will be geared towards supporting the economic recovery which has just started and also the ESC's recommendations to build a distinctive global city for all. 

 

    First of all, we will continue to maintain a stable property market which will underpin the economic recovery.  Mr Liang asked what are the indicators or fundamentals that Government looks at to determine if the property market is bubbly.  We do look at several indicators including price increases, transactions, sub-sales, and so on.  We do not have a specific set of indicators or trigger points that say that we should do certain things when some things happen. We are not on auto-pilot, in that sense. It is not only looking at indicators but having a sense of judgment as to what is likely to happen in the months going forward.

 

    As a result of that monitoring, we assessed that there was a high risk that a property bubble would be forming. In February, we introduced two measures to temper sentiments in the market. One was the decrease in the Loan to Value (LTV) ratio and the second was the imposition of a seller stamp duty. Why did we do this? Because in January, price increases had been strong and also the transactions were also at a high and the risk of over-heating was high. A property correspondent in Zaobao named Wu Hui Min put it this way: it is far better to take the liang cha (or cooling tea) now rather to take the tui shou yao (or aspirin) later on when the market is over-heated.

 

    Mr Chiam had asked for more measures to curb property prices.  I also remember Mr Hri Kumar asking for more severe measures to deter speculation.  Let me say that we do not intend to introduce more measures for now but we will monitor the market closely.  And if there are signs that the market will over-heat again, we are ready to introduce additional measures to stabilise the market.

 

   Dr Amy Khor asked a specific question about what she calls "Mickey Mouse" units, extra small units.  My view is that, beyond ensuring market stability, we should let market forces determine prices and also the type of unit sizes that they want to develop. But I do agree that the headlines about these units' high price per square foot (psf) are indeed misleading. I would suggest that we do more to educate consumers not to take such headlines at face value. 

 

     The second area of land use planning I want to emphasise is adequate land supply.  We will ensure that there is an adequate supply of land to support economic growth.  Mr Liang asked about foreign property buyers and also about whether the Government can provide more property market information.  Singapore is a key city in growing Asia.  I think it is understandable and natural and, indeed, not a bad thing that there is foreign interest in private residential properties here.  But having said that, properties in Singapore will still remain largely in the hands of Singaporeans. Singapore residents last year accounted for close to 90% of all private property housing transactions.  In the public housing market, the bulk of it is owned and occupied by Singaporeans. The Government will continue to ensure that there is adequate supply of private housing to meet the needs of both locals and foreigners through the Government Land Sales Programme which we announce twice a year.  URA also releases property market information to the public regularly. There is ample supply of private housing in the pipeline to meet demand over the next one to two years.  Buyers need not rush into the market. 

 

     Mr Liang also asked about further steps to pre-empt en bloc fevers. As he knows, this is under the purview of the Ministry of Law (MinLaw). MinLaw has been reviewing existing en bloc legislation and taken into account the feedback and the suggestions from the public. Any changes to en bloc rules will be made by MinLaw in due course.

 

     We will also continue to ensure that we have an adequate supply of commercial space in terms of both quantity as well as mix to support the ESC's objective which is to nurture a diverse eco-system of enterprises.

 

     In previous years, in the Committee of Supply, I had mentioned that we are planning to develop new growth areas in Jurong Gateway, Paya Lebar Central and also the Kallang Riverside. Despite the downturn, we have pressed on with infrastructure works and more sites at these areas will be progressively released for sale for development from this year onwards. Together with the grade "A" office spaces in the Central Business District (CBD), they will offer commercial firms more choice in business locations.

 

     We will further catalyse growth at Jurong Gateway and Paya Lebar Central by relocating several Government agencies out of the central area to Jurong as well as Paya Lebar.  My Ministry, the Ministry of National Development, and our statutory boards, AVA and BCA, will move to Jurong Gateway by 2015. The Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources and its statutory boards, PUB and NEA, are also planning to join us in Jurong.

     So, what constitutes an ideal healthcare system?  In my opinion, the characteristics of an ideal healthcare system can be illustrated by the acronym SAFE – S for Seamless, A for Affordable, F for Fast and E for Efficient.  When all the key qualities are achieved, the result is a safe and high quality healthcare system for all Singaporeans.  Much has been debated in the past about affordability and the provision of timely, quality medical services.  I would like to take this opportunity to discuss how we can work towards propelling our healthcare system to the next level of excellence.

 

     The recipe for a seamless healthcare system will include the following ingredients:

 

     (i) information technology (IT) infrastructural support;

 

     (ii) physical infrastructural development;

 

     (iii) building our medical manpower resources; and last but not least

 

     (iv) patient responsibility.

 

     First, IT infrastructural support. Imagine walking into any healthcare institution in Singapore, whether it is a public or private hospital, polyclinic or GP clinic, step-down care or nursing home, pharmacy or blood test laboratory. Your entire medical history, from the time you are born till you reach a ripe old age, is available to any healthcare provider, with just a push of the button or just reading the microchip in a national medical identity card.  The cornerstone of  a seamless healthcare is an efficient, effective IT infrastructure. There should be a national healthcare IT network to integrate all healthcare entities in the country. Beyond just simple connectivity, it demands a system that inter-operates seamlessly to reduce duplication, errors, waiting times and management overhead or costs, resulting in cheaper, safe and faster healthcare services.

 

     Second, physical infrastructural development.  The provision of physical healthcare infrastructure, such as hospitals, step-down care, nursing homes and primary healthcare facilities must be adequate to meet  the increasing demand from the increased population and ageing population.  The recent newspaper reports of shortages of hospital beds, patients waiting for prolonged periods at the Emergency Department before admission and the "alleged" premature discharge of unwell patients from hospital to free up beds are consequences of the inadequacy of healthcare infrastructure and, to a certain extent, a mismatch in the demand and the provision of medical services.  We can have the best surgeons, best physicians, best nurses and the most conducive clinics.  But if patients are made to wait long hours to be admitted, with long periods for their medical records to be traced and investigations repeated due to lack of integration with other healthcare entities, the whole patient experience of a seamless and efficient healthcare system will not be realised.  Without meeting the basic infrastructural requirements of a world-class healthcare system, we can never attain the goal of achieving a seamless healthcare system.
